title: DC Motors
explanation:
DC Motor Fundamentals

A DC motor is an electrical machine that converts direct current electrical energy into mechanical energy through the interaction of magnetic fields. DC motors are widely used in industrial applications due to their excellent speed control characteristics and high starting torque.

Basic Principle

DC motors operate on the principle that when a current-carrying conductor is placed in a magnetic field, it experiences a force. This is described by the equation:

$F = BIL$

Where:

  • F = Force (N)
  • B = Magnetic flux density (T)
  • I = Current (A)
  • L = Length of conductor (m)

üí° This force creates torque when applied to conductors arranged on a rotating armature, converting electrical energy to mechanical rotation.

EMF Equation

The back EMF generated in a DC motor is given by:

$E_b = \frac{P\phi ZN}{60A}$

Where:

  • $E_b$ = Back EMF (V)
  • P = Number of poles
  • $\phi$ = Flux per pole (Wb)
  • Z = Total number of conductors
  • N = Speed (rpm)
  • A = Number of parallel paths

Voltage Equation: $V = E_b + I_a R_a$, where V is supply voltage and $R_a$ is armature resistance.

Types of DC Motors

  • Series Motor: Field winding connected in series with armature
    • High starting torque: $T \propto I_a^2$
    • Variable speed: $N \propto \frac{1}{I_a}$
    • Applications: Electric traction, cranes, hoists
    • ‚ö†Ô∏è Never run on no-load!
  • Shunt Motor: Field winding connected in parallel with armature
    • Moderate starting torque: $T \propto I_a$
    • Constant speed (excellent speed regulation)
    • Applications: Lathes, machine tools, fans, pumps
  • Compound Motor: Both series and shunt field windings
    • Cumulative compound: Series field aids shunt field
    • Differential compound: Series field opposes shunt field
    • Applications: Rolling mills, heavy machine tools

Torque Equation

The torque developed by a DC motor is:

$T = \frac{P\phi ZI_a}{2\pi A}$

Where $I_a$ is the armature current.

Simplified form: $T = K_a \phi I_a$ where $K_a = \frac{PZ}{2\pi A}$ is the armature constant.

Speed Control Methods

The speed equation is: $N = \frac{V - I_a R_a}{K \phi}$

Three main methods:

  • 1. Flux Control Method: Varying field current changes flux œÜ
    • Since $N \propto \frac{1}{\phi}$, decreasing flux increases speed
    • Speed control above base speed
    • Most efficient method
  • 2. Armature Voltage Control: Varying applied voltage V
    • Speed control below base speed
    • Most common in modern DC drives
    • Provides wide speed range with constant torque
  • 3. Armature Resistance Control: Adding external resistance
    • Simple but inefficient: $P_{loss} = I_a^2 R_{ext}$
    • Poor speed regulation
    • Used for temporary speed reduction

Efficiency and Losses

Motor efficiency: $\eta = \frac{Output}{Input} = \frac{Output}{Output + Losses} \times 100\%$

Types of losses:

  • Copper losses (Variable): $P_{cu} = I_a^2 R_a + I_f^2 R_f$
  • Iron/Core losses (Constant): Hysteresis + Eddy current losses
  • Mechanical losses (Constant): Friction + Windage
  • Stray losses: Typically 1% of output

üéØ Condition for maximum efficiency: Variable losses = Constant losses

Starting of DC Motors

‚ö†Ô∏è Problem: At starting, $E_b = 0$, so starting current: $I_{start} = \frac{V}{R_a}$ (10-15√ó rated current!)

Starting methods:

  • 3-Point Starter: Series resistances + No-volt protection + Overload protection
  • 4-Point Starter: Independent field circuit (better for shunt motors)
  • Variable Voltage Starting: Using rectifiers or choppers (modern method)

Applications Summary

Motor Type Key Feature Applications
Series High starting torque Traction, cranes, elevators
Shunt Constant speed Lathes, fans, pumps
Compound Medium torque + fair speed regulation Rolling mills, presses

quiz.question: What is the basic principle of DC motor operation?
options: Force on current-carrying conductor in magnetic field
quiz.explanation: DC motors operate on the principle that when a current-carrying conductor is placed in a magnetic field, it experiences a mechanical force given by: $F = BIL$ where $B$ is magnetic flux density (T), $I$ is current (A), and $L$ is conductor length (m). This force causes the armature to rotate, converting electrical energy to mechanical energy.

quiz.question: In the EMF equation $E_b = \frac{P\phi ZN}{60A}$, what does 'A' represent?
quiz.explanation: In the EMF equation $E_b = \frac{P\phi ZN}{60A}$, the variable $A$ represents the number of parallel paths in the armature winding. For wave winding: $A = 2$, and for lap winding: $A = P$ (number of poles). This affects how conductors are connected and thus the voltage generated.

quiz.question: Which DC motor type has field winding in series with armature?
quiz.explanation: A series motor has its field winding connected in series with the armature, so the same current flows through both. This gives high starting torque but poor speed regulation, making it ideal for traction applications like trains and cranes.

exercises.problem: A 4-pole DC motor has 500 conductors with wave winding. If the flux per pole is 0.02 Wb and the motor runs at 1200 rpm, calculate the generated back EMF.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • P = 4 poles
  • Z = 500 conductors
  • N = 1200 rpm
  • œÜ = 0.02 Wb
  • Wave winding: A = 2

Formula:

$E_b = \frac{P\phi ZN}{60A}$

Step-by-Step Solution:

Step 1: Identify all values

P = 4, œÜ = 0.02 Wb, Z = 500, N = 1200 rpm, A = 2

Step 2: Substitute in the formula

$E_b = \frac{4 \times 0.02 \times 500 \times 1200}{60 \times 2}$

Step 3: Calculate the numerator

$= \frac{48000}{120} = 400$ V

Step 4: Final answer

Back EMF = 400 V

exercises.problem: A DC motor takes an armature current of 50 A at 220 V. The armature resistance is 0.3 Œ©. Calculate the back EMF and the power developed in the armature.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • V = 220 V
  • Ia = 50 A
  • Ra = 0.3 Œ©

Formulas:

$E_b = V - I_a R_a$

$P = E_b \times I_a$

Step-by-Step Solution:

Step 1: Calculate voltage drop across armature resistance

$I_a R_a = 50 \times 0.3 = 15$ V

Step 2: Calculate back EMF

$E_b = V - I_a R_a = 220 - 15 = 205$ V

Step 3: Calculate power developed

$P = E_b \times I_a = 205 \times 50 = 10,250$ W

Step 4: Final answer

Back EMF = 205 V
Power developed = 10.25 kW

exercises.problem: A 230 V DC shunt motor has an armature resistance of 0.5 Œ© and field resistance of 115 Œ©. At full load, the motor draws 40 A from the supply and runs at 1500 rpm. Calculate: (a) Field current, (b) Armature current, (c) Back EMF, (d) Speed if load torque is reduced by 50% and flux remains constant.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • Supply voltage, V = 230 V
  • Armature resistance, Ra = 0.5 Œ©
  • Field resistance, Rf = 115 Œ©
  • Line current at full load, IL = 40 A
  • Speed at full load, N‚ÇÅ = 1500 rpm

Step-by-Step Solution:

(a) Calculate Field Current:

In shunt motor, field is connected across supply voltage:

$I_f = \frac{V}{R_f} = \frac{230}{115} = 2$ A

(b) Calculate Armature Current:

Using Kirchhoff's current law: $I_L = I_a + I_f$

$I_a = I_L - I_f = 40 - 2 = 38$ A

(c) Calculate Back EMF:

Using voltage equation: $E_b = V - I_a R_a$

$E_b = 230 - (38 \times 0.5) = 230 - 19 = 211$ V

(d) Calculate New Speed when Torque Reduced by 50%:

Since $T \propto \phi I_a$ and flux is constant: $T \propto I_a$

If torque is halved: $I_{a2} = \frac{I_{a1}}{2} = \frac{38}{2} = 19$ A

New back EMF: $E_{b2} = V - I_{a2} R_a = 230 - (19 \times 0.5) = 230 - 9.5 = 220.5$ V

Since $N \propto \frac{E_b}{\phi}$ and flux is constant: $\frac{N_2}{N_1} = \frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}}$

$N_2 = N_1 \times \frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}} = 1500 \times \frac{220.5}{211} = 1500 \times 1.045 = 1567.5$ rpm

Final Answers:
(a) Field current = 2 A
(b) Armature current = 38 A
(c) Back EMF = 211 V
(d) New speed = 1567.5 rpm (speed increases when load decreases)
